Imagine a world where you can actually see what‚Äôs happening inside a Solana block.

Up until now this has largely remained a mystery, but that changes today!

2/ Let‚Äôs start with some context first.

When the team first started analyzing the data‚Ä¶

They expected to find a few outliers. 

Instead, they found widespread ùóπùóÆùòÅùó≤ ùóΩùóÆùó∞ùó∏ùó∂ùóªùó¥. 

What is it and why is it harmful to Solana? 

üëá
3/ ùóüùóÆùòÅùó≤ ùó£ùóÆùó∞ùó∏ùó∂ùóªùó¥ refers to the practice of concentrating transactions at the end of the slot. 

Since Solana is built as a streaming system, validators are expected to pack transactions throughout the slot while broadcasting block data as shreds over Turbine.
4/ Late Packing is harmful to the network because:
- Delays state propagation: leads to stale data & the network learns about prices later
- Increases execution variance: adds jitter as liquidations & auctions become unpredictable
- Undermines Turbine: degrades network efficiency
5/ Another issue known to the validator community = ùó¶ùóπùóºùòÅ ùóßùó∂ùó∫ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóöùóÆùó∫ùó≤ùòÄ.

Slot Timing Games refers to the practice where validators modify their Proof of History params to extend slot times beyond Solana‚Äôs default 360ms.
6/ ùó¶ùóπùóºùòÅ ùóüùóÆùó¥ùó¥ùó∂ùóªùó¥ is harmful to Solana because:
- Slows state transitions
- Increases end-to-end latency
- Decreases determinism
- Reduces application reliability
7/ So what is being done to fix this?

The IBRL Explorer introduces the IBRL Score to quantify validator block building performance for users and applications. 

The IBRL score is based on:
- Slot time score
- Vote packing score
- Non-vote packing score
8/ Scoring methodology

ùó¶ùóπùóºùòÅ ùóßùó∂ùó∫ùó≤ ùó¶ùó∞ùóºùóøùó≤ rewards speed, giving perfect scores for blocks built within specific limits (550ms for handoffs and 380ms for continuations) while decaying exponentially if those thresholds are missed.

ùó©ùóºùòÅùó≤ ùó£ùóÆùó∞ùó∏ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó¶ùó∞ùóºùóøùó≤ incentivizes timely consensus by giving perfect scores when at least 90% of vote txs are processed within the first 32 proof-of-history ticks, penalizing delays that push voting later in the block.

ùó°ùóºùóª-ùó©ùóºùòÅùó≤ ùó£ùóÆùó∞ùó∏ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó¶ùó∞ùóºùóøùó≤ evaluates whether transactions are packed consistently through a block vs. being back-end weighted.
9/ Since launching the IBRL Explorer internally, the tool has already proven useful for spotting various bottlenecks in the Solana network. 

One such trend was discovered in the last month, revealing unintentional late packing of votes across multiple data centers in Tokyo, Singapore, and other Asia regions. 

Believed to be related to submarine cable system failures affecting regional connectivity, this datapoint reveals itself in affected validators vote packing scores & is outside of their control.
10/ Another trend spotted using the IBRL Explorer is the cascading effect from late packing non-vote transactions. 

When one validator packs late, other validators receive shreds late, replay late, and vote late. 

It causes a ripple effect harming the network as a whole.
11/ The IBRL score is derived from observable leader behavior, but doesn't include all factors that can influence slot timing and tx distribution. 

Results may also be impacted by infrastructure, network conditions, and other variables not in the current methodology.

Think of it as a directional signal about block production and packing patterns, not a definitive assessment of validator intent or overall quality.

The team will continue refining the model and expanding the signal set over time to improve accuracy and reduce noise.

.@VitalikButerin just made a bold declaration: ETHEREUM HAS SOLVED THE BLOCKCHAIN TRILEMMA

He credits a new combination of technical upgrades that are working together to push the network‚Äôs scaling limit ‚Äì without sacrificing decentralization or security.

Today, we‚Äôre exploring where Ethereum is headed next. üëá

~~ Article by @JackInabinet ~~

üîç Ethereum‚Äôs Scaling Future

All networks make tradeoffs between decentralization, security, and scalability.

While peer-to-peer file sharing platform BitTorrent is highly decentralized and very scalable, it has no single source of truth that forms network consensus, providing weak security guarantees.

Although Bitcoin achieves strong decentralization and security guarantees, the network has an extremely slow throughput of approximately 7 transactions per second.

And while the Solana network delivers Bitcoin-like security at much faster speeds, the network‚Äôs hefty hardware requirements restrict participation to commercial-quality node operators, limiting decentralization.

The blockchain trilemma constrained the development of a balanced blockchain that simultaneously optimizes for decentralization, security, and scalability in each of these examples.

Yet, Vitalik Buterin believes Ethereum can achieve where others have failed using zkEVMs and PeerDAS.

üîí What are zkEVMs?

Zero-Knowledge Ethereum Virtual Machines (zkEVMs) are a type of scaling solution that executes Ethereum transactions offchain and proves their correctness back onchain using cryptographic zero-knowledge proofs.

Instead of individually submitting transactions to the Ethereum L1, zkEVMs bundle thousands of transactions together in a proof, which accounts for the results of transactions while circumventing the need for blockchain computation. This design increases scalability by using offchain execution, while preserving Ethereum-grade security via onchain proof verification.

Vitalik characterizes contemporary zkEVMs as ‚Äúalpha stage,‚Äù claiming they enjoy production-quality performance, but require safety work. He expects their full benefits to emerge over the next 4 years, with the first opportunities to run zkEVM nodes occurring sometime in the new year.

üì° What is PeerDAS?

Peer-to-Peer Data Availability Sampling (PeerDAS) is Ethereum‚Äôs latest leap in data scaling. It was adopted to mainnet on December 3, 2025, and served as the headline improvement of Ethereum‚Äôs recent Fusaka upgrade.

Rollups need to publish transaction data to Ethereum so the network can independently verify state transitions, and PeerDAS dramatically reduces the cost of making this data available by allowing nodes to sample small pieces of data from peers, rather than downloading entire data blobs.

PeerDAS (live today on mainnet) allowed Ethereum to increase the dedicated ‚Äúblob‚Äù storage space for data availability with no changes to the hardware requirements for nodes that want to validate the Ethereum L1.

üß≠ Where to Next?

Over the next four years, Vitalik believes that Ethereum can become the first network to fully conquer the blockchain trilemma. Such a breakthrough is not anticipated to be the outcome of a single sudden achievement; rather it is expected to be the gradual result of sustained progress over time.

Ethereum has already expanded data availability through PeerDAS, and while developers expect initial zkEVM node experiments to begin this year, Buterin doesn‚Äôt anticipate zkEVMs will become a dominant method of block validation until later this decade.

Although execution risk remains, should Vitalik‚Äôs scaling vision materialize, Ethereum could very well redefine what‚Äôs possible for decentralized systems, offering a model where security, decentralization, and scalability reinforce one another instead of competing.
